ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: on average 3-4 but more during midterm and final project
2 to 5, depending on assignments due
3-5 hours per week, assignments are tedious and make you feel like you are in high school again
7 hours on average
2.5 hours/week
6-8 hours per week
2-3 hrs on avg, 4-5 for papers
3-4 hours
3 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Excellent - might be a little better if there were more exchange with students instead of almost entirely lecture style.
Strengths: Interesting topics, fair gradingWeaknesses: None
Great blend of domestic and international nutrition issues, which appeals to people of different backgrounds.

Great course! This is not a topic I had any experience with before this semester, and Dr. P-E did a wonderful job providing a solid overview of the material, yet also managing to cover the topics in depth. I think the format was good, and I am glad I was able to take the class.
Wonderful insight and real life experiences shared by Prof Perez-Escamilla!!

I thought that the lecture material was interesting and well-taught.The weekly write-ups were a bit monotonous. Also, I felt that the expectations for the final paper were a bit too high since not everyone has experience with health policy or doing systematic reviews.

This is an excellent course for anyone interested in maternal and child health. Dr. Perez-Escamilla is extremely knowledgeable and provides a great overview of current issues and approaches to evidence based research& policies.
The final assignment should be clarified in terms of what is expected.

Be prepared to discuss only topic areas that are of interest to the professor, particularly breast feeding. An courses designed around evidence based medicine, most of the course is rattling off various studies and results from those studies. Final paper is a systematic review, but prepare for unclear guidance on the subject matter or format of the paper.

Overall, this course was well-structured and interesting.Final project was a scholarly review but at no point in course was methodology for such a review introduced. It would be helpful to have a lecture on the basics of a scholarly, systematic review including electronic search strategies and the structure of a review. A librarian could even be brought in to discuss electronic search strategies for a systematic review.

This course has been one of my favorite classes at YSPH! The strengths of the course are its ability to examine various aspects of nutritional policies domestically and internationally. There were always political, economic, cultural and social dynamics to each lecture which gave a comprehensive and thorough examination of each topic. The course also did well by incorporating discussion and lecture during the class-period. No weaknesses.

This class covered a wide variety of topics in maternal and child public health nutrition, which I really enjoyed. I believe the weekly summaries, however, could be replaced with short writings that require more synthesis rather than summarization.

Everything about this course could be classified as an strengh. The summaries were great because it help students prepare for the coming lecture and allows us to come up with ideas for our final paper. I also enjoy the 10 minute presentation. Everyone was on time and all presentations were great.

This was an excellent course - our professor was incredible! His ability to supplement the course material with his own experiences was a huge strength of the course. The course had few readings, but each was pertinent for the presentation that week - making the readings useful and too overwhelming.There are no weaknesses of the course.

Strengths- variety of interesting topics related to public health nutrition- opportunity to do substantial research on a topic of interestWeaknesses- some of the class structure (according to the syllabus) didn't work because the class was very large
Great course, very interesting. Nice balance of policy, nutrition, CDE.

The weekly lectures were always intriguing and insightful. The readings also further helped us understand the concept/topic of the week. The weekly write-ups, which were basically summaries of an article that we read, were helpful at the beginning of the semester, however, it became more of a routine mid-way through the semester and perhaps a little redundant. The final project, which comprised of a systematic review and presentation, was a great exercise. The presentations were all very interesting.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Very knowledgeable! Amazing!
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Awesome - a true expert in the field. Balances constructive criticism with words of encouragement.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Fantastic!
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Wonderful! Great lectures, feedback, etc.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Professor Perez-Escamilla is a good teacher. He clearly knows a lot about the topics of the course. That said, it did not seem like he cared too much for the students. He was approachable in the sense that he was willing to meet with you, but he was not the easiest person to solicit help from. If I am struggling with something class-related, I expect a professor to be supportive and helpful.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Engaging& extremely knowledgeable
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla is engaging and knowledgeable.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Professor epitomizes the academic focus of Yale, interested in his own work more than the students and the perspectives they bring to the table.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Sensitive to students but could provide better, more detailed feedback (particularly on outline for final paper). It seemed that the professor had a very specific idea of what he wanted for the final paper (i.e. topic that evaluated evidence underpinning a particular policy or program) but he did not convey this to students at outset of course.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla is a wonderful instructor- he challenged us by helping us to critically analyze articles related to the nutritional topics. He was enthusiastic about his work and his passion showed in every lecture.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla is exceptionally knowledgeable in this field. I particularly enjoyed hearing about his wide array of experiences both at the local and national level, such as at the US Dietary Guidelines lecture.I believe the instructions for the final paper and presentation could have been more clearly explained from the beginning of the semester. More specific feedback on our topics and outlines might have been helpful as well.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla was amazing. He provided the students with wonderful feedback and ideas for our paper. Also he gave us very strong syllabus and detail instructions for every assignment, which was very helpful for the students. It was very nice to have the presence from Dr. Rodrigo Venna from Brazil during each class. He also provided us with his input on how things are done in Brazil. Both were amazing.

Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Prof. Perez-Escamilla was outstanding. He was one of the best instructors that I have had at YSPH, and if I could we take any other course he taught. He is a great lecturer, has a wealth of experience in the field and does an excellent job of teaching this information in a digestible way. I do not have any recommendations for how his teaching could be improved.
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  - Very articulate and passionate about teaching- Engaging and creative approach to policies and practices in public health nutrition
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Great!
Instructor: Rafael Perez-Escamilla  Dr. Perez-Escamilla is a wonderful lecturer. I recommend taking this class, and attending all the lectures.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A lecture-style survey course of various topics that relate to maternal and child PH nutrition.
Yes! Rafael is a great person to learn from.
A look at policies and research related to maternal and child public health nutrition. Looks at relevant policies and decisions being made in the US related to these issues.
If you enjoy maternal-child health or nutrition, I would recommend this class.
see response to question 6
This courses provides the opportunity to learn about and discuss several specific and relevant topics in maternal and child nutrition, especially from a policy perspective.
This highly regarded class was a let down. It was boring, uninformative, and a lot of busywork.

Maternal and PublicHealth Nutrition is a course describing various public health nutrition hot topics in the U.S. and abroad. The topics range from exclusive breastfeeding protocol, conditional cash transfers, and dietary intake of fish. I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in infectious or chronic diseases, environmental health and policy. The course does well by incorporating these various public health interests with nutrition.

The course covers numerous topics in the field of maternal and child public health nutrition. In addition to specific health topics, it also discusses important policies in the field.I would highly recommend this class to anyone interested in this topic.
I would 100% recommended to anyone who interested in public health. I feel it is a must take class if you are interested in improving health from the very beginning.

Yes, I would recommend this course to others. It is a great course that provides a thorough summary of maternal, child health and nutrition. The professor is amazing, and students who do not have a background in this topic can still follow all of the material.
Preview course for topics in maternal and child public health nutrition, including policy and practice issues.
If you are interested in mat/child health and or nutrition, this is a great course
